translation.content: Iʾm very happy to see you!

transcription.content: Hola, Luisa, baʾax ka beetik teech.
Hola, Luisa, ba'ax ka bèetik tèech.

translation.content: Hi, Luisa, what are you doing?
Me, Iʾm going for a walk.

transcription.content: Teneʾ tin chan bin j maan.
Tene' tin cham bin j màan.

translation.content: Good luck to you! (may it go well with you)

transcription.content: Táan u chan bin j xíimbal.
Táan u chàam bin j xíimbal.

translation.content: Heʾs going to the square, too.

section.description: "neutral" in pitch (no mark) and short in duration (single vowel)

notes.note: This section describes and illustrates the vowel sounds of Maya as they combine with three Maya accents. In words of one syllable, these are:

section.description: high (or gliding) in pitch (´) and long in duration (written double)

notes.note: This section describes and illustrates the vowel sounds of Maya as they combine with three Maya accents. In words of one syllable, these are:

section.description: low (or level) in pitch (`) and long in duration (written double)

notes.note: This section describes and illustrates the vowel sounds of Maya as they combine with three Maya accents. In words of one syllable, these are:

section.description: "neutral" in pitch with both syllables of equal intensity

notes.note: This section describes and illustrates the vowel sounds of Maya as they combine with three Maya accents. In words of two syllables, these accents manifest themselves in slightly different ways:

section.description: high (or gliding) in pitch on the first syllable with greater intensity on the first syllable

notes.note: This section describes and illustrates the vowel sounds of Maya as they combine with three Maya accents. In words of two syllables, these accents manifest themselves in slightly different ways:

section.description: low (or level) in pitch on the first syllable, with greater intensity on the first syllable

notes.note: This section describes and illustrates the vowel sounds of Maya as they combine with three Maya accents. In words of two syllables, these accents manifest themselves in slightly different ways:
If the examples which differ only in accent are presented one after the other, the differences become more apparent.
If the examples which differ only in accent are presented one after the other, the differences become more apparent.

translation.content: In the phrases: (a) bey xan teen "thus, too, me" , (b) kux teech "as for you" , and (c ) letiʾ xaneʾ "him, also, concerning" we find the pronouns: teen "I", teech "you", and letiʾ "he/she/it" used either (a) independently or (b) (c) to reinforce an otherwise expressed subject. In all these expressions they indicate single individuals.
You greet a friend, you say:
You ask where he is going:
I'm very glad to see you.

section.description: Julio meets Luisa on the Road

transcription.content: Hola Luisa, baʾax ka chéen beetik.
Chéen mix baʾal, Julio. Tuʾux ka bin.
Kux a sukuʾun, tuʾux ku bin.
Bey xan teen tin bin j maan.
Kiʾimak in wóol in wilikech. Tuʾux ka bin.
Táan in chan bin j xíimbal.

section.description: A approaches B (whose name is Julio), greets him and asks what he's doing. B replies and then asks how A is. After replying to that, A says he has to go and B bids him goodbye.
A asks B where he's going. B replies that he's going in the square. A says he's also going to the square and that he's going shopping.
A says he's glad to see B. B say likewise and asks what A has to say. A says there's nothing; he's just going shopping. B bids him well and takes leave.
